column15: 'textDisplay': "One interesting fact that didn‚Äôt make it into the piece is that movie theaters didn‚Äôt always have consistently great sound ‚Äî it only became consistent thanks to Star Wars. \n\nThe story goes like this: George Lucas was trying to find a theater to premiere ‚ÄòReturn of the Jedi.‚Äô and every theater he went to had terribly set up sound systems. He was like
column16: ‚ÄúThis is unacceptable! Why am I asking all of my sound designers
column18: and mixers to put in all this work if I can't guarantee it‚Äôs going to be heard properly on playback?‚Äù \n\nSo he enlisted Tomlinson Holmman to create
column20: that THX ‚Äî the one with the way-too-loud booming sound at the beginning of all those old movies you used to watch as a kid. THX was a sound quality certification made to ensure that ‚ÄòReturn of the Jedi‚Äô was presented in the purest form possible. But it did so much more than that by standardizing good sound playback in movie theaters across the board. \n\nSound has progressed a ton since then
column21: but Star Wars set the precedent for good sound quality in theaters.\n\nFor more awesome content about sound in your favorite movies and TV shows
column22:
check out Austin on TikTik: https://www.tiktok.com/@aok.wav

Thanks for watching! 
‚ÄîEd"

column75: 'textDisplay': "As an English teacher and non-native speaker myself
column76: I get asked a lot by my students whether they'll be able to eventually watch movies without the subtitles. It feels lame to tell them that I don't do that myself
column77: but I'm honest with them about that anyways. I understand YouTube videos and podcasts fully no problem
column78: but not movies. After watching this video
column79: I indulge myself to feel actually relieved that the limitation is not on my part
column80: but a phenomenon that affects most people
column81: native speakers and all. Thanks! I'll let my students know about that!"

column421: 'textDisplay': "This reminds me of my theatre kid days. I tended to be hard to hear and we often didn't have mics. Eventually I learned to speak more clearly not just by raising volume
column422: but by adjusting my pitch and register to keep them out of phase with the ambient noise I was currently sharing space with. Sometimes crisper is better than louder."
column423: 'textOriginal': "This reminds me of my theatre kid days. I tended to be hard to hear and we often didn't have mics. Eventually I learned to speak more clearly not just by raising volume
column424: but by adjusting my pitch and register to keep them out of phase with the ambient noise I was currently sharing space with. Sometimes crisper is better than louder."

column448: 'textOriginal': "The worst is when we go to the theater

column471: 'textDisplay': "This is such a huge relief. There have been several times where I think something is wrong with me. I don't have trouble hearing. column639: 'textDisplay': "When I was in audio engineering school
column640: I remember downmixing being a big part of one of my final exams. I had to take the taxi chase scene from The 5th Element
column641: replace every sound effect with ones I'd chosen from a library
column642: mix it in 5.1 and then downmix it to stereo in about four hours. Up until that point
column643: I had really wanted to go into post production audio work but the idea of doing that every day kinda soured me on the idea."
column644: 'textOriginal': "When I was in audio engineering school

column669: 'textDisplay': 'Also I noticed as of 5-10 years ago my family and I started complaining of the sound effects in movies and TV shows being much louder than the dialogue - even to this day I\'m constantly having to turn the sound down for action scenes and back up again during moments of dialogue. It\'s annoying and reduces immersion because I\'m constantly having to look for the remote and adjust the volume. I always just thought it was our stereo sound system but this video makes me think otherwise. The "Nolan effect" in real time in my living room'
column670: 'textOriginal': 'Also I noticed as of 5-10 years ago my family and I started complaining of the sound effects in movies and TV shows being much louder than the dialogue - even to this day I\'m constantly having to turn the sound down for action scenes and back up again during moments of dialogue. It\'s annoying and reduces immersion because I\'m constantly having to look for the remote and adjust the volume. I always just thought it was our stereo sound system but this video makes me think otherwise. The "Nolan effect" in real time in my living room'

column791: 'textDisplay': "It's comforting to know that I am not alone in using subtitles
column792: not only for English dialogue (which has become blurrier to me in recent years) but also for my native language
column793: Italian. Sometimes the music track in a film produced in Italy is sooooo loud that the dialogue becomes unintelligible in parts. Being partly deaf now and working in video and sound QC for a video distribution company
column794: I have been noticing this from a technical standpoint as well. My suggested solution would be: DO NOT use effects and music when it is not absolutely necessary!"
column795: 'textOriginal': "It's comforting to know that I am not alone in using subtitles
column796: not only for English dialogue (which has become blurrier to me in recent years) but also for my native language
column797: Italian. Sometimes the music track in a film produced in Italy is sooooo loud that the dialogue becomes unintelligible in parts. Being partly deaf now and working in video and sound QC for a video distribution company
column798: I have been noticing this from a technical standpoint as well. My suggested solution would be: DO NOT use effects and music when it is not absolutely necessary!"
column819: 'textDisplay': 'DVDs and streaming services should deliver their movies with separate tracks for music
column821: so that consumers can choose if they want to experience the recommended settings or to tune around for their own liking.'

column945: 'textDisplay': "I didn't even realize people actually used subtitles very much.  I've never noticed very many people using subtitles IRL anyway.  I've been using them quite a bit the last few years.  I listened to quite a bit of loud rock/metal music on headphones when I was a kid
column946: and also was stupidly running chainsaws for about 5 years without using ear protection as much as I should have.  I was guessing I have a combo of slightly bad hearing and my fleeting attention span.  I believe I may have had ADHD or something my whole life because my attention span has always been really bad
column947: long before the internet era.  I never had myself officially checked out for it. \n\n But anyway
column948: I have to rewind stuff all the time because I frequently can't understand what is being said
column949: or simply zone out due to my attention problems.  If it gets too bad I just turn the subtitles on
column950: but I hate using them because it distracts from the visual element."

column1247: 'textDisplay': 'I‚Äôm a re-recording mixer.  This video leaves out what is in my opinion the biggest factor.  They explained how a wide dynamic range has a negative effect in home environments but did not elaborate and did not explain that we have no choice but to mix with these wide dynamics due to network requirements
column1248: which most of us mixers want changed!!  Television used to be mixed with very little dynamics.  But now the line between TV and film is blurred and companies like Netflix want their content to ‚Äúsound theatrical‚Äù so they require us to keep the dialog at a -27dB average while allowing us to peak at -1 for the big moments.  That range is too wide for most homes because of the acoustic environment.  Acoustics play SUCH a huge role in how we hear things
column1249: I can not overstate this enough.  Without proper absorption in the walls and corners you get all kinds of buildups of certain frequencies that resonate the room
column1250: especially during loud moments.  So often times it‚Äôs the room itself that‚Äôs muddying the dialog and not even the speakers or the mix.  Any kind of natural reverberation in the room also makes dialog a little less intelligible so the natural response is to turn it up during the quiet moments.  Then suddenly the loud moments become WAY too loud due too resonant frequencies in the room.  The fix for this is to mix with a narrower dynamic range but the networks won‚Äôt allow us to do that.. for now.  I always tell people to try listening in headphones and I guarantee you won‚Äôt be riding the volume up and down cause you‚Äôve eliminated the room out of the equation.'
column1251: 'textOriginal': 'I‚Äôm a re-recording mixer.  This video leaves out what is in my opinion the biggest factor.  They explained how a wide dynamic range has a negative effect in home environments but did not elaborate and did not explain that we have no choice but to mix with these wide dynamics due to network requirements
column1252: which most of us mixers want changed!!  Television used to be mixed with very little dynamics.  But now the line between TV and film is blurred and companies like Netflix want their content to ‚Äúsound theatrical‚Äù so they require us to keep the dialog at a -27dB average while allowing us to peak at -1 for the big moments.  That range is too wide for most homes because of the acoustic environment.  Acoustics play SUCH a huge role in how we hear things
column1253: I can not overstate this enough.  Without proper absorption in the walls and corners you get all kinds of buildups of certain frequencies that resonate the room
column1254: especially during loud moments.  So often times it‚Äôs the room itself that‚Äôs muddying the dialog and not even the speakers or the mix.  Any kind of natural reverberation in the room also makes dialog a little less intelligible so the natural response is to turn it up during the quiet moments.  Then suddenly the loud moments become WAY too loud due too resonant frequencies in the room.  The fix for this is to mix with a narrower dynamic range but the networks won‚Äôt allow us to do that.. for now.  I always tell people to try listening in headphones and I guarantee you won‚Äôt be riding the volume up and down cause you‚Äôve eliminated the room out of the equation.'

column1815: 'textDisplay': "I'm a native German speaker and like to watch TV series in English if it's the original language. And to me it was always interesting when you switch the language that you will need to increase the volume when you switch from dub to original. Because of course in the original version you have all the problems described in the video while in the dubbed version the voices are much louder and clearer. Interestingly this is rarely a problem when watching original German series. Of course then it's my native language but the voices are much clearer compared to original English ones."
column1816: 'textOriginal': "I'm a native German speaker and like to watch TV series in English if it's the original language. column1983: 'textDisplay': 'True fact: I used to work as a subtitle editor for major hollywood studios
column1984: and even we sometimes had trouble figuring out what was being said in the dialogue... and we (usually) had access to the scripts!'

column2007: 'textDisplay': "That's a truly excellent piece of explanation - and every word clear!   Long ago
column2008: I swung a mic boom for BBC-tv plays and documentaries. We strove for absolute intelligibility: proper mic just above actor's head
column2010: discussion (let's call it that!) with camera operator about 'top of frame' positioning
column2011: realistic sound perspectives.  We greatly disliked body-worn mics
column2012: muffled under costume and unrealistic proximity.    In the dubbing theatre we were conscious that viewers rarely had speakers as good as ours
column2013: nor did they have the benefit of a script
column2014: so we would play the mix through a telly speaker in a boomy cabinet to check clarity.  The video makes a keen point about scooping the spectrum to keep SFX and voices apart.   More use of that might just rescue some dialogue from modern mumbling!"
column2015: 'textOriginal': "That's a truly excellent piece of explanation - and every word clear!   Long ago

column2521: 'textDisplay': "So glad to hear it's not only me... My impression always was that original versions of US-produced films are very hard to understand - especiall for me being non-English-native. I thought it's probably me not knowing English well enough to follow their films
column2522: but apparently they just have different styles of filming and mixing. I'm glad we do not (yet) have that in productions from all other parts of the world"
